title: 107_hr5531
content: The Act may be cited as the "Sudan Peace Act". The Congress finds that the Government of Sudan's intensified war outside its control has resulted in over 2,000,000 deaths and 4,000,000 displaced. A comprehensive peace process, humanitarian relief, and U.S. leadership are crucial for a lasting resolution in Sudan. The absence of credible civil authority in Sudan hinders self-sustenance and peace progress. The government uses divide-and-conquer tactics through traditional rivalries, but international reconciliation efforts have helped reduce suffering. Militias are organized for raiding and enslaving in areas outside government control. The Government of Sudan disrupts populations in areas outside its control to avoid international accountability. It plans to use oil sales to escalate the war in these areas and manipulates food aid as a weapon to starve targeted groups. The Government of Sudan's actions, including genocide, are outside of international control. Efforts by the United States and other donors have helped address deficiencies in aid delivery, offsetting Sudan's manipulation of food donations in the civil war. While immediate needs in some areas have been met, populations in areas outside government control still face extreme disruption. The Nuba Mountains and other regions remain at risk. The Nuba Mountains, Bahr al Ghazal, Upper Nile, and Blue Nile regions are excluded from relief distribution by OLS, increasing famine risk. International relief operations are costly and unsustainable, focusing only on immediate food needs. Populations in areas outside government control are vulnerable due to disengagement of front-line states. The United States should apply pressure. The United States should use various means of pressure to facilitate a comprehensive solution to the war in Sudan, including multilateralizing economic and diplomatic tools, supporting democratic institutions in areas outside government control, promoting reconciliation mechanisms, strengthening humanitarian relief mechanisms, and cooperating with trading partners and multilateral institutions. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "appropriate congressional committees," "Government of Sudan," and "OLS." SEC. 4. CONDEMNATION OF SLAVERY, OTHER HUMAN RIGHTS ABUSES, AND TACTICS OF THE GOVERNMENT OF SUDAN. This section condemns slavery, human rights abuses, and tactics of the Government of Sudan. The Congress condemns violations of human rights in Sudan, including the Government's role in the slave trade and aerial bombardment of civilian targets. The Congress condemns human rights violations in Sudan, including the Government's involvement in the slave trade and aerial bombardment of civilian targets. It also acknowledges the use of raiding and slaving parties by the Government of Sudan to create food shortages and destroy the societies of the Dinka, Nuer, and Nuba peoples. The President is authorized to provide increased assistance to areas of Sudan not controlled by the government for peace and democratic governance, including support for civil administration, infrastructure, education, health, and agriculture. $100,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2003-2005. Amounts appropriated remain available until expended. Support for an internationally sanctioned peace process is also included. Congress recognizes the importance of a viable peace process for resolving the conflict in Sudan, based on key agreements. Special Envoy Danforth's efforts are commended for working towards a just and lasting peace. The President must report to Congress every 6 months on the negotiations between the Government of Sudan and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement. If the President determines that Sudan is not negotiating in good faith or interfering with humanitarian efforts, measures will be implemented after consultation with Congress. If the President certifies that the Sudan People's Liberation Movement is not negotiating in good faith for peace, then certain measures will be implemented. If the Government of Sudan is not compliant with a peace agreement, the President will take action after consulting with Congress. If the Government of Sudan resumes negotiations in good faith or complies with a peace agreement, certain measures in support of the peace process will not apply. The President can instruct international financial institutions to vote against any extension of loans to Sudan and consider diplomatic actions. The United States may downgrade or suspend diplomatic relations with Sudan, deny Sudan access to oil revenues for military purposes, and seek a UN arms embargo on Sudan. If Sudan halts negotiations with the Sudan People's Liberation Movement, the President must report on the status. The President must submit quarterly reports on the peace process status if negotiations with the Sudan People's Liberation Movement are halted. The Secretary of the Treasury must report on US opposition to financing by international financial institutions, and the President must submit a plan for denying oil revenues within 45 days of taking action. In this section, the term "international financial institution" refers to specific organizations such as the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the International Development Association, the International Monetary Fund, the African Development Bank, and the African Development Fund. SEC. 7. MULTILATERAL PRESSURE ON COMBATANTS. The United Nations should facilitate peace and recovery in Sudan. The President should work to end Sudan's veto power over relief flights and implement measures to stop slavery and aerial bombardment of civilians. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress every year on the conflict in Sudan, detailing the financing and construction of oil infrastructure, the impact on local residents, the government's ability to fund the war with oil proceeds, and the extent of aerial bombardment by Sudan. The report to Congress on the conflict in Sudan includes details on targets, frequency, and damage caused by the Government of Sudan, as well as the obstruction of humanitarian relief efforts. SEC. 9. Congress urges increased use of non-OLS agencies for relief efforts in southern Sudan. President to submit progress report within 90 days. SEC. 10. Contingency plan required for potential ban on air transport relief flights. SEC. 10. The President must create a contingency plan to ensure the delivery of relief to Sudan, including the Nuba Mountains and the Blue Nile regions, in case of a ban on OLS air transport flights. The President has the authority to reprogram funds for this plan. The Secretary of State is required to collect information on potential crimes in Sudan and submit detailed reports to Congress. This includes incidents of crimes against humanity, genocide, war crimes, and violations of international humanitarian law. The reports must be submitted within 6 months of the enactment of the Act and annually thereafter. The Secretary must consult with other departments in preparing these reports. The Secretary of State must consult with other government officials to complete reports on potential crimes in Sudan, without disclosing sensitive information that could jeopardize national security interests.
